intro: Polycarpon gayi, commonly known as the coastal morning glory, is a flowering plant native to coastal regions of southern Australia. It is a herbaceous annual that typically grows to a height of about 30–60 centimeters. The plant produces trumpet-shaped flowers that are usually pale blue or purple, blooming from late spring to early autumn. Its leaves are alternate, heart-shaped, and covered in fine hairs. The species is adapted to sandy soils and can tolerate salt spray, making it well-suited to coastal environments.
